com.googlecode.transmuter.converter
Class ConverterType

java.lang.Object
  com.googlecode.transmuter.converter.ConverterType

public class ConverterType
extends Object

Represents a converter's "type": the input type (called fromType) paired with its output type (called toType). Converter types are immutable.

Author:
Humberto S. N. dos Anjos

from

public static ConverterType from(Method method,
                                 Type ownerType)
                          throws ObjectInstantiationException
Creates a new converter type extracting the information from a method object and it's owner type. The owner type is used to resolve generic types referenced or inherited by the method.

Several checks are made to see if the given method is a valid converter method, with each error associated to an exception. All the exceptions, if any, are bundled up in a ObjectInstantiationException for throwing. The checks made are:

  • method cannot be null. This error forces a ConverterTypeInstantiationException containing a single IllegalArgumentException.
  • ownerType cannot be null. This error forces a ConverterTypeInstantiationException containing a single IllegalArgumentException.
  • method must be invokable on ownerType. This error forces a ConverterTypeInstantiationException containing a single MethodOwnerTypeIncompatibilityException.
  • method must have one and only one parameter (signals a WrongParameterCountException).
  • method's parameter must be a non-generic type (signals a InvalidParameterTypeException).
  • method's return type cannot be void (signals a InvalidReturnTypeException).
  • method's return type must also be non-generic (signals a InvalidReturnTypeException).

Parameters:
method - a method object.
ownerType - the specific instance class to which the given method belongs.
Returns:
a new ConverterType instance.
Throws:
ObjectInstantiationException - if there are errors while extracting the information.

from

public static ConverterType from(Binding binding)
                          throws ObjectInstantiationException
Creates a new ConverterType instance using the information from the given binding. Calling this is equivalent to calling from(Object, Method) with the binding's instance and method.

Parameters:
binding - a binding.
Returns:
a ConverterType instance constructed from binding.
Throws:
ObjectInstantiationException - if binding is null or cannot be used to create a converter type.
See Also:
from(Method, Type), Binding.getInstanceClass(), Binding.getMethod()

isAssignableFrom

public boolean isAssignableFrom(ConverterType converterType)
Checks if the types used in the given converter type are also compatible with the types in this instance.

Returns:
if the types used in the given converter type are also compatible with the types in this instance, or false if the given converter type is null.

equals

public boolean equals(Object obj)
Two converter types are equal if they are assignable from each other.

This is the same as checking the equality of its types, with one exception: converter types containing primitive types are considered equal to converter types which differ only by holding the correspondent wrapper types. Examples: 

 new ConverterType(String, boolean).equals(new ConverterType(String, Boolean))
 new ConverterType(Byte, Object)   .equals(new ConverterType(byte, Object))
 new ConverterType(int, Character) .equals(new ConverterType(Integer, char))

Overrides:
equals in class Object

hashCode

public int hashCode()
Given ConverterType's equality definition, converter types with primitive types must have the same hash code as equivalent converter types with corresponding wrapper types.

Overrides:
hashCode in class Object
